questions.questionText: Drag reactants to complete the following Williamson Ether Synthesis:
questions.correctFeedback: Correct! You've successfully completed the Williamson Ether Synthesis. Sodium methoxide (a strong nucleophile) attacks bromoethane (an alkyl halide) in an SN2 reaction to form methyl ethyl ether.
questions.incorrectFeedback: Incorrect. For Williamson Ether Synthesis, you need a strong nucleophile (an alkoxide) and an alkyl halide. Try again!
questions.chemistryNotes:
The Williamson Ether Synthesis is an important method for preparing ethers:

  • It involves an SN2 reaction between an alkoxide ion (RO-) and an alkyl halide (R'-X)
  • The alkoxide acts as a nucleophile and attacks the electrophilic carbon of the alkyl halide
  • The halide is displaced as a leaving group
  • The general reaction is: R-O- + R'-X → R-O-R' + X-

This reaction works best when the alkyl halide is primary or methyl, as these are most susceptible to SN2 reactions with minimal competing elimination.

questions.questionText: Select the reagents needed for this SN1 reaction to form tert-butyl ethyl ether under acidic conditions:
questions.correctFeedback: Correct! This SN1 reaction uses tert-butyl chloride (which forms a stable carbocation) reacting with ethanol to form tert-butyl ethyl ether.
questions.incorrectFeedback: Incorrect. This is an SN1 reaction. Think about which reagent would readily form a carbocation and which would act as the nucleophile.
questions.chemistryNotes:
The SN1 (Substitution Nucleophilic Unimolecular) reaction occurs in two steps:

  1. The leaving group departs, forming a carbocation intermediate
  2. The nucleophile attacks the carbocation

Key characteristics:

  • Rate depends only on the concentration of the substrate (unimolecular)
  • Common with tertiary or secondary substrates that form stable carbocations
  • Follows first-order kinetics
  • Often occurs in polar protic solvents that can stabilize the carbocation

In this case, tert-butyl chloride readily forms a stable tertiary carbocation, which is then attacked by ethanol acting as a nucleophile.

questions.questionText: Select reagents to complete this E2 elimination reaction:
questions.correctFeedback: Correct! The strong base potassium tert-butoxide abstracts a hydrogen (deprotonation) from 2-bromo-2-methylpropane, causing elimination of HBr and forming the alkene 2-methylprop-1-ene.
questions.incorrectFeedback: Incorrect. For an E2 elimination reaction, you need a strong base and an alkyl halide. The base abstracts a hydrogen while the halide leaves simultaneously.
questions.chemistryNotes:
E2 (Elimination Bimolecular) reactions occur in a single step:

  • A strong base abstracts a proton while the leaving group departs simultaneously
  • This creates a new π bond (C=C)
  • Rate depends on both substrate and base concentration (bimolecular)
  • Often favored with bulky bases like tert-butoxide
  • Follows anti-periplanar geometry (H and leaving group must be anti to each other)

The reaction is concerted, meaning bond breaking and bond formation happen simultaneously. E2 reactions generally require:

  1. A suitable leaving group (like a halide)
  2. A strong base
  3. A β-hydrogen that can be abstracted

questions.questionText: Complete this acid-catalyzed esterification reaction by selecting the correct reagents:
questions.correctFeedback: Correct! This is a Fischer esterification reaction where acetic acid reacts with ethanol to form ethyl acetate (an ester) and water. The reaction is typically catalyzed by an acid like H2SO4.
questions.incorrectFeedback: Incorrect. Esterification requires a carboxylic acid and an alcohol. Try again with the correct combination.
questions.chemistryNotes:
Fischer Esterification is the acid-catalyzed reaction of a carboxylic acid with an alcohol to form an ester:

  • General reaction: RCOOH + R'OH ⇌ RCOOR' + H2O
  • The reaction is reversible and reaches equilibrium
  • Typically catalyzed by a strong acid (H2SO4, HCl, p-toluenesulfonic acid)
  • Can be driven forward by:
    • Using excess of one reagent
    • Removing water as it forms

Mechanism steps:

  1. Protonation of the carboxylic acid carbonyl
  2. Nucleophilic attack by the alcohol
  3. Proton transfer
  4. Loss of water to form the ester
  5. Deprotonation to form the final product

questions.questionText: Select reagents for this Grignard reaction to form 2-phenylethanol:
questions.correctFeedback: Correct! The Grignard reagent (phenylmagnesium bromide) acts as a nucleophile and attacks ethylene oxide. After acidic workup, this forms 2-phenylethanol.
questions.incorrectFeedback: Incorrect. Grignard reactions involve a Grignard reagent (R-MgX) acting as a nucleophile. Consider which reagent would serve this role.
questions.chemistryNotes:
Grignard Reactions use organomagnesium compounds (Grignard reagents) as strong nucleophiles:

  • Grignard reagents have the formula R-MgX (where X is a halide, typically Br or Cl)
  • They behave as sources of nucleophilic R- groups (carbanions)
  • They react with various electrophiles including:
    • Aldehydes and ketones to form alcohols
    • Epoxides to form alcohols with chain extension
    • CO2 to form carboxylic acids
  • Must be performed under anhydrous conditions (Grignard reagents are destroyed by water)
  • Typically carried out in ether solvents like diethyl ether or THF

In this case, the phenylmagnesium bromide opens the ethylene oxide ring, creating a new C-C bond and forming 2-phenylethanol after workup.

questions.questionText: Select reagents for this acid-base neutralization reaction:
questions.correctFeedback: Correct! This is a simple acid-base neutralization reaction where acetic acid (a weak acid) reacts with sodium hydroxide (a strong base) to form sodium acetate and water.
questions.incorrectFeedback: Incorrect. This is a basic acid-base neutralization. Try selecting a carboxylic acid and a suitable base.
questions.chemistryNotes:
The Acid-Base Neutralization is one of the most fundamental reactions in chemistry:

  • An acid donates a proton (H+) to a base
  • This forms a salt and, typically, water
  • The general reaction is: HA + BOH → BA + H2O

In this specific case:

  1. Acetic acid (CH3COOH) is a weak acid with a pKa of about 4.76
  2. Sodium hydroxide (NaOH) is a strong base that fully dissociates in water
  3. When mixed, the hydroxide ion (OH-) accepts a proton from acetic acid
  4. This forms sodium acetate (CH3COONa) and water (H2O)

This reaction is commonly used in acid-base titrations and is an essential concept in understanding buffer solutions.

questions.questionText: Select reagents for this simple SN2 reaction:
questions.correctFeedback: Correct! This SN2 reaction shows the nucleophilic substitution of the bromine in 1-bromobutane with a hydroxyl group from sodium hydroxide, forming 1-butanol.
questions.incorrectFeedback: Incorrect. An SN2 reaction needs a good nucleophile and a substrate with a good leaving group. Try again!
questions.chemistryNotes:
The SN2 (Substitution Nucleophilic Bimolecular) reaction is a fundamental type of nucleophilic substitution:

  • A nucleophile attacks a carbon bearing a leaving group
  • The reaction occurs in a single step (concerted mechanism)
  • Inversion of stereochemistry occurs at the reaction center (if chiral)

Key features of SN2 reactions:

  1. Rate depends on both nucleophile and substrate concentrations (bimolecular)
  2. Works best with primary and methyl substrates (less steric hindrance)
  3. Polar aprotic solvents typically accelerate the reaction
  4. Good leaving groups (like bromide) facilitate the reaction

In this example, hydroxide (OH-) acts as the nucleophile, attacking the carbon attached to bromine in 1-bromobutane. The bromine leaves as bromide (Br-), forming 1-butanol as the product.

questions.questionText: Select reagents for this alcohol dehydration reaction:
questions.correctFeedback: Correct! Concentrated sulfuric acid dehydrates ethanol to form ethene (ethylene) by removing a water molecule. This is a basic elimination reaction.
questions.incorrectFeedback: Incorrect. Alcohol dehydration requires an alcohol and a strong acid catalyst. Try again with the correct combination.
questions.chemistryNotes:
The Dehydration of Alcohols is an elimination reaction that forms alkenes:

  • Involves the removal of a water molecule (H2O) from an alcohol
  • Typically requires a strong acid catalyst and heat
  • Follows an E1 mechanism with secondary and tertiary alcohols
  • May follow an E2 pathway with primary alcohols

General conditions:

  1. Strong acid (H2SO4 or H3PO4) protonates the OH group
  2. This converts the poor OH leaving group into a good H2O leaving group
  3. Heat provides the energy needed for the elimination
  4. Follows Zaitsev's rule (the more substituted alkene predominates)

In this example, ethanol (a primary alcohol) is dehydrated to ethene using concentrated sulfuric acid at elevated temperatures. This is one of the simplest dehydration reactions and represents a fundamental method for alkene synthesis.

questions.questionText: Select reagents for this primary alcohol oxidation:
questions.correctFeedback: Correct! Potassium dichromate (K2Cr2O7) in acidic conditions oxidizes ethanol (a primary alcohol) to acetaldehyde. This is a controlled oxidation that stops at the aldehyde stage.
questions.incorrectFeedback: Incorrect. To oxidize a primary alcohol to an aldehyde, you need an appropriate oxidizing agent and controlled conditions. Try again!
questions.chemistryNotes:
The Oxidation of Primary Alcohols can produce either aldehydes or carboxylic acids, depending on the reagents and conditions:

  • Primary alcohols can be oxidized to aldehydes under controlled conditions
  • Further oxidation can convert aldehydes to carboxylic acids
  • The choice of oxidizing agent and reaction conditions determines the final product

For aldehyde formation:

  1. K2Cr2O7 in acidic conditions (H2SO4) can oxidize primary alcohols to aldehydes
  2. The reaction must be controlled (typically by distilling off the aldehyde as it forms)
  3. The orange Cr(VI) is reduced to green Cr(III) during the reaction
  4. Other reagents like PCC provide more selective oxidation to aldehydes

In this example, ethanol is oxidized to acetaldehyde using potassium dichromate in acidic conditions. Keeping the reaction conditions controlled prevents further oxidation to acetic acid.

questions.questionText: Select reagents for this amide formation reaction:
questions.correctFeedback: Correct! Acetic acid reacts with ammonia to form acetamide. This direct amide formation requires heating to overcome the energy barrier.
questions.incorrectFeedback: Incorrect. Amide formation requires a carboxylic acid (or derivative) and an amine. Try again with the correct combination of reagents.
questions.chemistryNotes:
The Formation of Amides is a key reaction in organic and biological chemistry:

  • Amides are formed from carboxylic acids and amines
  • Direct reaction between these groups is possible but typically requires heat
  • The reaction involves nucleophilic acyl substitution
  • Water is eliminated during the reaction

Mechanism of direct amide formation:

  1. Nucleophilic attack by the amine nitrogen on the carbonyl carbon
  2. Proton transfer steps
  3. Elimination of water
  4. Formation of the amide bond (C-N)

While direct heating of carboxylic acids with amines can form amides, more efficient methods include:

  • Converting the acid to an acid chloride first (more reactive)
  • Using coupling reagents like DCC
  • Using acid anhydrides as acylating agents

In this example, acetic acid reacts with ammonia upon heating to form acetamide, a simple and fundamental amide. This type of bond is critical in proteins (peptide bonds) and many pharmaceuticals.
